Similarly with Yosef, once they verified through seeing his milah (circumcision) that he was a tzaddik (righteous person), they then believed in the sign of his speech when he spoke in Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew). Also, his speech was visible to the physical sense of sight. Our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, sent Yehudah ahead of him to prepare the way to Goshen, and to establish a Beis Medrash (house of study) as our Sages said. Seemingly, Yosef himself could have prepared this, or it could have been done through any of the other tribes, so why did he send Yehudah who was king?

It appears to be explained based on the Midrash regarding "and he saw the wagons that Yosef sent" - where were the wagons that Pharaoh sent? It teaches that those wagons that Pharaoh sent to carry him had idolatrous images engraved on them, so Yehudah stood up and burned them. This tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah (idolatry). The Yefeh Toar and Nitzotzei Kedushah questioned why Yosef didn't burn them himself, and they answered that since Yehudah was especially suited for this task, it was left to him. The Nitzotzei Kedushah elaborates based on the Midrash that "we are not as expert in the details of avodah zarah as our father Yaakov," and similarly, Yehudah was expert in the details of avodah zarah.

Therefore, Yaakov sent Yehudah because he could recognize and discern even hidden aspects of avodah zarah, including thoughts of idolatry, as that tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah. Since Yaakov wanted to establish a house from which Torah instruction would emanate, it required careful discrimination to ensure there would be no trace of avodah zarah, and only Yehudah was suited for this as mentioned above. Therefore, he specifically sent Yehudah to prepare the Beis Medrash, ensuring it would be completely free of any trace of avodah zarah, and from there Torah instruction would emerge.

From this, we can see how carefully one must guard against the ways of avodah zarah, requiring extra wisdom to understand, distinguish, and separate from them. This connects to the halachah they taught: "When do we make the blessing over fire at the conclusion of Shabbos? Our rabbis taught that we don't make the blessing until we can benefit from its light." This is because extra recognition is needed to make distinctions, and where did they learn this from? From the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it says, "And God saw the light that it was good" and afterward "God separated between the light and the darkness." For this reason, he sent Yehudah ahead, because extra discernment was needed to prepare a Beis Medrash that would be suitable and worthy for Torah instruction to emanate from it.

It is explained in the holy sefarim that the 12 tribes of G-d correspond to the 12 permutations of the Divine Name (Havaya), and each permutation indicates a different middah (attribute) and aspect. According to this, each one served Hashem in a different way and approach. This is what the Midrash means when it says that the lion and ox argue with each other - their middot and ways of service are not the same, but "He makes peace in His heights" means that regarding kavod shamayim (Heaven's honor), there is peace between them without any separation at all, and each one unifies their heart to the Holy One, Blessed be He.

It is known that our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, encompassed all the middot together. This explains what our Sages said in the Midrash that his sons said to Yaakov, "Just as in your heart there is only One, so too in our hearts there is only One." This means that although in our actions in serving Hashem there are differences between one and another, in the inner depths of our hearts we have only one heart.

This aspect is alluded to in the words of the Midrash here that "Yehudah did not move from there until he understood his heart," meaning he understood the inner heart of Yosef and recognized that there was peace between them, and they all served with one intention to unify their hearts to the Holy One, Blessed be He. The differences between them were only in the outer actions. Therefore, after he understood his heart, he realized there was no separation between them at all. May Hashem help us to unify our hearts to His blessed Name in truth.

Now we will explain why Yosef needed both proofs together, since each proof was a complete verification as mentioned above. If so, one should have been sufficient. One can explain that although it was verified to them through seeing the milah (circumcision) that he was a complete tzaddik (righteous person), as they saw upon him the Divine Presence (hashra'at Shemo Yitbarach) as mentioned above, and it was impossible to mistake him for an Arab who was circumcised or from the children of Keturah.

However, they still had room for doubt, as it was possible that there was another tzaddik in the land who guarded the bris (covenant) and had the holy name (shema kadisha) rest upon him, and he wasn't Yosef. Perhaps he was only changing his speech to ease their minds and for the sake of Heaven (l'shem shamayim) by saying he was Yosef, because he saw their spiritual distress. However, their doubts were resolved through seeing his language capability, for regarding the aspect of language that was at the level of "seeing what is heard," which is impossible except through the Divine Presence (hashra'at HaShechinah) speaking through his throat. From this they knew that his mouth and heart were aligned and he wasn't changing his speech, for the Divine Presence cannot rest upon false speech, Heaven forbid. If the words weren't truthful, even in a permitted way such as changing for the sake of peace or because of danger, it would have been impossible for the Shechinah to speak through his throat. Even though technically, according to the law, benefit from such an item would not be forbidden, as it's not even considered tashmishei avodah zarah (implements of idol worship), but due to their great holiness, they were careful to avoid even the slightest hint of avodah zarah, as mentioned above.

The observance of Torah and mitzvos was their entire life force, and without it, they considered themselves as if their life force had been cut off. This is what they meant when they said "with whomever of your servants it is found, he shall die." Meaning, if someone would be found with something connected to avodah zarah, they would consider him as dead, as if his life force had been cut off, for they didn't consider anything to be "life" except that which was attached to and unified with the Torah, as mentioned above.

One who merits the hashra'as haShechinah (Divine Presence) is called "alive," as Rashi explains on the verse "and the spirit of their father Yaakov was revived" - that the Shechinah, which had departed from him, returned to rest upon him. And certainly, one who stumbles even slightly in matters of avodah zarah cannot merit the hashra'as haShechinah.

Therefore, they said "with whomever of your servants it is found, he shall die," meaning his life force would be cut off and the hashra'as haShechinah, which is called "life," would depart from him. Their intention was not to sentence him to actual death, but rather to provide proof to remove from Yosef's heart the suspicion that they had stolen the goblet. We can explain the verse "to establish for you a remnant in the land, etc." based on what is said in the Gemara regarding ribis (interest) [Bava Metzia 75b]: Those who transgress the negative commandment are the lender, borrower, guarantor, and witnesses. Abaye said the lender transgresses all [prohibitions], etc., while the guarantor and witnesses only transgress "you shall not place upon him interest."

The Gemara [62a] asks: While all others perform an action, what action do the witnesses perform? Rather, is it not that the very act of establishing [the loan] is significant? Thus, even though the guarantor and witnesses didn't perform an actual deed in the matter itself, because the transaction was completed through them, they are liable for the prohibition of "you shall not place," with the root of the action being included in the word "placing."

Similarly, in our matter, Yosef HaTzaddik preceded going to Egypt to prepare a place for Bnei Yisrael so they could maintain their kedushah (holiness) in Egyptian exile, which was the ervat ha'aretz (most defiled land) and extremely contaminated. Through the power of his kedushah and the trials he withstood and overcame, and by becoming ruler over the sar (angel) of Egypt, he weakened the power of tumah (impurity) and klipot (negative forces) at their root.

Through this, Israel merited to be protected from immorality in Egypt - "Bnei Yisrael entered and Bnei Yisrael left" - and not one of them was born from improper relations, as our Sages said. Moreover, Yosef HaTzaddik prepared a power of salvation for future generations until the final exile, so that Israel could overcome and withstand the trials of exile and maintain their kedushah even in the terrible lowliness of ikveta d'meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), as the Egyptian exile is the root of all exiles.

The holy Avot and Shevatim were the root of all Jewish souls throughout the generations, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root. Therefore, through their holy actions, they opened a channel and prepared strength for all generations of Israel. This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. This is the holy spark which is hidden within the nefesh (soul) of every Jew, inherited from our holy forefathers. At first, it is only at the level of a "remnant," but afterward, the boundary of kedushah expands "to sustain you for a great deliverance."

I explained based on the Gemara in Berachos (18) where there is a dispute whether the deceased know of the pain of the living or not. The Gemara's conclusion is that they don't know unless they are informed. See the Maharsha's words there (beginning with "And if you think they don't know").

However, regarding Yaakov Avinu a"h, Chazal taught that he is compared to his descendants - just as his descendants are alive, so too is he alive. Chazal said "Yaakov Avinu did not die," and therefore he feels the pain of his children more than all the other Avos.

The holy Alshich writes in Parshas Vayechi that whenever Scripture mentions death regarding Yaakov, it uses the name "Yisrael," as it says "And Yisrael said to Yosef, behold I am dying," and "The days of Yisrael drew near to death," and other similar instances. However, with [the name] Yaakov, it only mentions "expiration" (geviah). He explains that the great additional level that was added to his nefesh, ruach, and neshamah when he was called Yisrael is what departed from him... Therefore, whenever death is mentioned, the name Yisrael is used. But regarding the aspect of Yaakov, which was his original level, he didn't depart but rather "expired" like someone who fainted, as all the powers of his nefesh, ruach, and neshamah remained essentially connected to him.

The Yismach Moshe z"l wrote in Tefillah L'Moshe (124) that the name Yaakov hints to the aspect of galus (exile), as the Yud is from Hashem's name, and "ekev" (heel) is an expression of lowliness, hinting to the exile where "I am with him in distress." For this reason, the name Yaakov was not uprooted.

The main point is that Yaakov Avinu a"h suffers with us in the pain of exile, and the greatest exile is the lowliness of Torah in our many sins. Therefore, when we support and establish Torah institutions and support children's Torah education, we are doing a kindness for Yaakov Avinu/Yisrael Saba, for he suffers and feels the pain of exile and the lowliness of Torah. Yosef HaTzaddik, with his holy power, prepared strength for all future generations so they could withstand great trials. The holy tribes worked greatly for the sake of future generations until the coming of Mashiach, and through his holy power achieved that even in the lowly generations, at least remnants of the holy Torah would remain and the Torah would not, God forbid, be completely forgotten from Israel.

This is what is meant by "And God sent me before you to establish" - which refers to the power of Torah, as they interpreted through the gezeirah shavah of "establish-establish" as mentioned above. And this means "to establish for you a remnant in the land" - that at least remnants of Torah's power would remain in all generations. And through maintaining these remnants, they will later merit "to sustain you as a great deliverance" at the time of Mashiach's coming, when they will merit the complete power of Torah.

This is hinted at in saying "to sustain you," meaning at the time when there will be "sustaining for you" - which is the time of resurrection when Moshe, Aharon, the generation of the desert, and all the holy tzaddikim will arise. Then there will be a great deliverance, through having maintained the remnants of the holy Torah during the time of lowliness. This explains why the verse begins with "remnant in the land" and concludes with "great deliverance" - for through maintaining the remnants, they will later merit a great deliverance at the time of resurrection, speedily in our days.

Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

I explained based on the Gemara in Berachos (18) where there is a dispute whether the deceased know of the pain of the living or not. The Gemara's conclusion is that they don't know unless they are informed. See the Maharsha's words there (beginning with "And if you think they don't know").

However, regarding Yaakov Avinu a"h, Chazal taught that he is compared to his descendants - just as his descendants are alive, so too is he alive. Chazal said "Yaakov Avinu did not die," and therefore he feels the pain of his children more than all the other Avos.

The holy Alshich writes in Parshas Vayechi that whenever Scripture mentions death regarding Yaakov, it uses the name "Yisrael," as it says "And Yisrael said to Yosef, behold I am dying," and "The days of Yisrael drew near to death," and other similar instances. However, with [the name] Yaakov, it only mentions "expiration" (geviah). He explains that the great additional level that was added to his nefesh, ruach, and neshamah when he was called Yisrael is what departed from him... Therefore, whenever death is mentioned, the name Yisrael is used. But regarding the aspect of Yaakov, which was his original level, he didn't depart but rather "expired" like someone who fainted, as all the powers of his nefesh, ruach, and neshamah remained essentially connected to him.

The Yismach Moshe z"l wrote in Tefillah L'Moshe (124) that the name Yaakov hints to the aspect of galus (exile), as the Yud is from Hashem's name, and "ekev" (heel) is an expression of lowliness, hinting to the exile where "I am with him in distress." For this reason, the name Yaakov was not uprooted.

The main point is that Yaakov Avinu a"h suffers with us in the pain of exile, and the greatest exile is the lowliness of Torah in our many sins. Therefore, when we support and establish Torah institutions and support children's Torah education, we are doing a kindness for Yaakov Avinu/Yisrael Saba, for he suffers and feels the pain of exile and the lowliness of Torah. Thus, this kindness reaches him, and his merit should protect us and all of Israel.
